title: 105_hr4286
content: The "Parent-Child Privilege Act of 1998" may be cited as the Parent-Child Privilege. Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence introduces the Parent-Child Privilege, defining terms like 'child' and 'confidential communication'. The Parent-Child Privilege under Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence protects confidential communications between a parent and a child from being disclosed in court proceedings. The privilege applies to psychotherapists, social workers, clergy members, and other third parties with a confidential relationship with the parent or child. Parents cannot be compelled to testify against their child in civil or criminal proceedings. The Parent-Child Privilege under Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence protects confidential communications between a parent and a child in court proceedings. Parents and children cannot be compelled to testify against each other unless they voluntarily waive the privilege. The Parent-Child Privilege under Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence protects confidential communications between a parent and a child in court proceedings, even if the parent or child is deceased or the relationship has ended. Exceptions include civil actions between the parent and child, when the parents are opposing parties, or in cases contesting the parent-child relationship. The Parent-Child Privilege under Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence applies in various legal proceedings involving the child or parent, including civil actions contesting the estate, custody disputes, commitment hearings for mental or physical incapacity, and criminal or juvenile cases involving offenses against the child or parent. The Parent-Child Privilege under Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence allows for the appointment of a representative for a child below the age of majority in legal proceedings. This rule does not affect other evidentiary privileges. This rule does not affect other recognized evidentiary privileges that may be applicable in legal proceedings governed by these rules. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents for the Federal Rules of Evidence. Rule 501, the parent-child privilege, applies to communications made before, on, or after the enactment of this Act.
